snippet: Twelve years after a too-close-to-call presidential contest in Florida ended in a divisive Supreme Court ruling, the United States’ voting methods are as laden with problems as ever.
abstract: United States’ voting systems, twelve years after too-close-to-call presidential contest in Florida ended in divisive Supreme Court ruling, remain as deeply flawed as ever; prospects of fixing some of the worst problems, like voter registration, ballot design, and absentee voting, are mired in increasing levels of partisanship.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years after a too-close-to-call presidential contest in Florida ended in a divisive Supreme Court ruling, the United States’ voting methods are as laden with problems as ever.

headline.seo: Voter ID Issue Is One of Many for U.S. Voting Systems
headline.main: Partisan Rifts Hinder Efforts to Improve U.S. Voting System
headline.print_headline: Efforts to Fix Voting Flaws Fall Victim To Politics
